data.title: Class of 2011
data.meta_description: Click here to view this item from http://www.missoulian.com.
data.text:
Tanner Lavering

Co-salutatorian

Florence-Carlton

So one day I was sitting in China Buffet, gorging on a variety of Asian dishes from orange chicken to pork fried rice, when I was given an epiphany in the form of a small strangely shaped cookie. In that moment I decided to base my speech to you, my fellow students, off the fortune cookies that sat before me that day. I figured I could give no better advice than advice straight from a cookie.

Chase Furlong

Co-salutatorian

Loyola Sacred Heart

The way I see it, everyone experiences high school in a different way. Some people regard it as the best time of their lives, others not so much ... Good memories aside, I am excited to be moving on.

Hollyn Wittmier

Co-valedictorian

Valley Christian

None of us were born yesterday and all of you know that the life that we lead from here on out will test everything that we learned and let characterize us here. Within this next year especially, many will begin to change into the people that they will be for the rest of their lives. We've had protection and spiritual nurturing here but now, ready or not, we embark on a new journey away from the normality of safety that has surrounded our lives.

Breanna Wight

Valedictorian

Drummond

All of our experiences have prepared us for today, but they will now lie behind us. The future is still in that path ahead of us. What is most important is that right now we have it in us to be whatever we want to be. Now is the time that we need to step up and believe in ourselves and in what we can do and who we can be.

Brooke Sauro

Valedictorian

Loyola Sacred Heart

Our class had our moments just as all families do. There was some drama, fighting and times when we simply could not tolerate each other. Regardless, I think we all can agree, our last months were ones of growth and healing. We came to realize that although we have our differences, we will always be there for each other. We will always respect and love one another. We are family.

Geoffrey Glidewell

Co-valedictorian

Valley Christian

I know one of my classmates hates it when people say we are about to enter the "real world. " If we haven't entered the "real world" yet, he asks, then where have we been living for the past 18 years? But, what those people mean is that we are ending the time in our lives with these same restrictions. We can still take advice from others, but what our actions will be is determined by ourselves, not others. To put it simply, we have freedom.

Shawn Sacchi

Co-valedictorian

Thompson Falls

Throughout high school you learn a lot. You remember a little. You try a lot, and you regret some. People will tell you to have no regrets, but I will tell you this: Have no regrets of wasted opportunities. There is no sense regretting events that never took place. We have futures to look forward to. Instead, keep in hindsight the regrets of those opportunities taken because those are the regrets that help shape who you are, and who you will become.

Thomas Mitzel

Co-salutatorian

Loyola Sacred Heart

You always hear kids say how the teachers care about you and how they want you to succeed. But they prove it everyday they walk into the classroom. They come to teach you and make you better, and they expect you to come ready to learn. For that, I cannot thank them enough. These students and teachers created an environment where talk meant nothing, and action meant everything. It has made me grow as a student, friend, brother and son.

Jadi Curtis

Co-salutatorian

Loyola Sacred Heart

I want all of my classmates to know that I have faith that each one of you will grow and flourish, and that I can't wait to see what great things you go on to accomplish. Never doubt your own potential for it may be more magnificent that even you understand.

Natasha Wood

Co-valedictorian

Thompson Falls

Never let other people influence what you have your mind set upon. Never lower your standards or give up hope. Keep going for what it is that you want to accomplish. And never forget, "Live the life you have imagined."

Julian Thorne

Co-salutatorian

Florence-Carlton

So don't worry our education isn't squandered. Sure we may not use algebra, but we've learned how to work through problems and to have logic be our guide. We may never have a need to write the ubiquitous five-paragraph essay but we know how to organize our thoughts and express ourselves intelligently. Perhaps most of all we have learned to communicate and interact with those around us.

Katherine Hawkins

Co-valedictorian

Valley Christian

We have been given talents we didn't deserve, abilities we didn't ask for, and when we have a successful career - a successful life - we shouldn't forget the one who brought us out of the slavery of sin into His wonderful light. To God be the glory!

Top seniors

Erik Anderson

Parents: John and Susan Anderson

GPA: 4.0

Activities: Cross country; track; Brain Bowl Academic Team; Computer Science Team; National Honor Society.

Scholarships, awards: National Merit Scholarship; Governor's Best and Brightest Scholarship; Siemens Award for Advanced Placement; Montana State University Provost Scholarship.

Future: Study computer engineering at Montana State University.

Parents: Steve and Hazel Bixby

GPA: 4.0

Activities: Varsity soccer; National Honor Society; Advanced Band; basketball; Pep Band; Campus Life; district and state music festivals; freshman mentor; Gifted Education mentor; student government; youth track coach.

Scholarships, awards: Academic All-State; All-Conference soccer; first chair, flute; superior ratings at district and state music festivals; Most Inspirational Soccer Player; Coach's Award; Montana University System Honor Scholarship; Whitworth Mind and Heart Scholarship; Fox University Presidential Scholarship; Plum Creek Community Scholarship; Burger King Scholars Scholarship; Missoula Federal Credit Union Lefty Campbell Memorial Scholarship.

Future: Pursue a degree in elementary education or premed at Whitworth University.

Parent: Beth Cole

Scholarships, awards: Plum Creek Scholarship; Elks Most Valuable Student Award; Montana State University Premier Scholarship; Montana University System Honor Scholarship; Seattle University Trustee Scholarship; Presidential Award for Public Service; Northwestern Scholarship.

Future: Attend Northwestern University; major undecided.

Future: "I plan on becoming a physical therapist and will begin my education at the University of Montana Davidson Honors College."

Kelsie Miller

Parents: Steve and Pattie Miller

Activities: Junior varsity golf; basketball; varsity track; cross country; varsity swimming; Key Club; student government; Model United Nations; Prom Committee.

Scholarships, awards: Seattle University Campion Scholarship; University of Portland Legacy Scholarship; Lake Forest College Presidential Scholarship; Whitworth College Legacy Scholarship; St. Patrick Hospital Friends and Family Scholarship; Elks Student of the Month; Community Medical Foundation Scholarship.

Scholarships, awards: Montana State University Premier Scholarship; Montana University System Honor Scholarship; Hammond Scholarship.

Miranda Tornatore

Parents: Jenny Tornatore and Mike Tornatore

Activities: Key Club; student government; Prom Committee; Missoula Youth Symphony; Advanced Problems in Science; Leadership High School; school board representative; National Honor Society; varsity swimming.

Scholarships, awards: Wendy's High School Heisman Award; Lyle R. Heath Community Service Award; KPAX Student Service Award; International Science and Engineering Fair; Elks National Foundation Most Valuable Student Scholarship; Arizona State Swimming Scholarship and Academic Achievement Scholarship; Georgia Tech Swimming Scholarship; University of Minnesota Swimming Scholarship; San Diego State Swimming Scholarship; New American University Provost Award.

Future: Attend Arizona State University to study engineering and swim.

Top seniors

Jadi Curtis

Scholarships, awards: Three-time state speech and debate champion; valedictorian; Georgetown University 1789 Scholarship and Sultan Qaboos bin Said of Oman Scholarship; University of Rochester Bausch & Lomb Science Scholarship; Gettysburg College Abraham Lincoln Presidential Scholarship; Montana State Elks Association Most Valuable Student Scholarship; Hellgate Elks Lodge Most Valuable Student Scholarship; Community Medical Center Foundation Dr. Timothy and Tonda Richards Scholarship; Missoula Federal Credit Union Scholarship; Exchange Club Youth of the Year Scholarship; Montana University System Honor Scholarship; University of Montana Davidson Honor Scholarship; Music Teachers Association Frederic Chopin Piano Award; Air Force Mathematical and Science Award.

Future: Major in Arabic and chemistry at Georgetown University.
